sentence: Chicago, IL - February 22, 20Array6 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog.
Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets.
Stocks recently featured in the blog include Walt Disney Co. ( DIS ), The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ), Apple Inc ( AAPL ), Microsoft Corp. ( MSFT ) and Wal-Mart Stores Inc ( WMT ).
Today, Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.
Get #ArrayStock of the Day pick for free .

Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:

The Dow enjoyed significant gains during a holiday shortened week.
The index increased after markets opened on Tuesday following broad-based gains.
The index gained for the third consecutive day on Wednesday following a sharp rally in oil prices and encouraging economic data.
However, the Dow experienced a decline on Thursday following volatility in oil prices and weak results from a key component.
The Dow has moved upward during two of the week's three trading sessions, gaining 4.3%.
The index increased Array.4% after markets opened on Tuesday following broad-based gains.
Friday's better-than-expected retail sales report continued to boost consumer discretionary shares on Tuesday.
Dow components, The Walt Disney Co. ( DIS ) and The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ), increased 2.7% and Array.9%, respectively.
Apple Inc's ( AAPL ) shares rose 2.8% after the tech giant said that it will sell bonds worth $Array0-Array2 billion in order to pay dividends and to support its repurchase program.
Dow component Microsoft Corp. ( MSFT ) advanced Array.2%.
Financial stocks continued to rally on Tuesday.
JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs increased Array.5% and 2%, respectively.
Meanwhile, earlier in the day, increase in oil prices helped boost energy shares following hopes of an agreement between Russia and key OPEC members like Saudi Arabia on a production cut.
However, oil prices failed to hold on to gains after Russia, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Qatar said crude output levels will remain constant, ruling out the possibility of a production cut.
Chances further slimmed after Iran declined to make any immediate production cut.
Exxon Mobil increased 0.2% but Chevron decreased 0.7%.
Separately, China's new yuan loans reached its highest level ever of 2.5Array trillion yuan.
The index gained for the third consecutive day on Wednesday, by Array.6%, following a sharp rally in oil prices and encouraging economic data.

Oil prices moved northward following news that Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh indicated that the country is ready to support Saudi Arabia and Russia's move to maintain the current level of crude production.
Exxon Mobil and Chevron advanced Array% and 4.Array% respectively.
Meanwhile, PPI increased 0.Array% in January, in contrast to the consensus estimate of a decrease of 0.2%.
Industrial production increased 0.9% in January, more than the consensus estimate of a 0.3% increase after slipping 0.7% in December.
However, housing starts decreased 3.8% from December.

Separately, the minutes on Federal Reserve's January meeting released on Wednesday indicated that Fed officials may wait for an improvement in the U.S. economic outlook and accomplish an inflation rate of 2% before deciding on a rate hike.
The index declined by nearly 0.3% on Thursday following volatile oil price movement and weak outlook for the next quarter and fiscal year from Wal-Mart.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc's ( WMT ) shares fell by 3% to its lowest level since October.
The company was the biggest loser among the Dow components.
Meanwhile, Iran supported Saudi Arabia and Russia's move to keep crude production constant, boosting oil prices in early trading.
However, the rally ended after Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel Al Jubeir stated Saudi Arabia is not ready to cut its crude output at this time.
Moreover, the Energy Information Agency reported that crude inventories increased by 2.Array million barrels for the week ending Feb Array2 to 504.Array million.
Chevron fell Array.8% but Exxon Mobil Corp increased 0.6%.
Additionally, possibilities of a rate hike in March dimmed following comments from key Fed officials.
These developments also raised concerns that a low rate environment may hurt the profits of financial companies.
JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs decreased Array.6% and 2.Array%, respectively.
